# Introduction

R Markdown is a simple way to combine text, R code, and math in one file. It lets me explain what Iâ€™m doing, show my code, and display the results all together. This makes it easier to keep my work organized and reproducible.

# Narrative Section

In this assignment, I learned how Markdown formatting works, like using headings, bold text, lists, and inline code. I also learned how R code chunks run inside the document. This makes it easier to write a report while also showing the code that produced my results.

Here is an example of **inline math**: $a + b = c$.

And here is a displayed equation:

$$
y = mx + b
$$

# R Code Examples

Below is my first code chunk, which loads a dataset and shows the first few rows.

```{r setup}
library(ggplot2)
```

```{r}
# Load data
data(mtcars)
head(mtcars)
```

```{r}
ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "MPG vs Horsepower")
```
